bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 26, 1941

div1.p: Truby points out historical inaccuracies found in the yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 26, 1941
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Annexure of addendum #2
(in England) to by letter
of Aug 29, 1941
(started Aug 26
Aug. 26/41
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have been too busy lately
to answer your letter of Aug 19 and
the one of Aug 23 to Mr. Kellogg. (with
a copy for me). I thought your comment
in the latter were fine and fair to all
concerned. In they key to the painting
I find no errors except that no. 12,
Moran, was actually a civilian clerk
at Gen. Lee's Headquarters and was
not an acting Hospital Steward at that
time as he did not re-enlist when
his term as an elisted enlisted man
expired several weeks before the Reed
Board went to work in Cuba. I mentioned
that in a letter to Mr. Kellogg to-day
but suggested that no changes be made
until you are consulted.

The nicely framed engineer's reproduction
of the Y.F. painting came today and I
was much pleased with it in every respect.
I think Mr. Cornwell has produced a
really fine painting and with the re-
grouping, (since the first sketch I saw)
my first objections have been removed
AC
T
2
there is one small error which I
mentioned to Mr Kellogg. Officers did
not wear the silver cross on their
campaign hats. The enlisted men were
the only ones permitted to wear it.
That can readily be corrected on the
painting but probably not on the prints.

I also told Mr. K. that if they decided
to put Ames in the picture it could be
done without a stroke of the brush by
simply designating the officer in white
(on the porch) as Ames and the one in Khaki
as Cooke. The one in white with the
dark hair could readily pass for Ames
and the one in from looks more like
Cooke than the one in white does.

I was surprised that the medical History
of the Post at Columbia Bks was such
a “dud”. I really thought that Stark
had written that up. He should have
done so starting when the Board arrived and
then reported progress from time to time.
He was, however, completely absorbed
in his surgical work and never did care
for administrative work. You must see
some of the old Medical Histories. At the
Hospital, Governor's Island, N.Y. you
will find a most interesting set of
these old volumes and good accounts
of yellow fever epidemics there, way
back in the 19th century. At Ft Robinson
Nebraska there are some old medical
Histories with pages written by Walter Reed
3_
when he was stationed there Back in the 1880-90. When
you run out of work I suggest that
you write to the Surgeon there and see
if they can be located. They were in
the attic of the hospital and not well
cared for, but the War Dept. won't permit
of their removal from the Post. Walter
Reed's entries should be microfilmed or
copied in some way. Have you read
the book “Old Jules” by Mari Sondaz
pub. by Little, Brown & Co. 1935? It
has a Photostat copy of one of Reed's
letters from Ft Robinson dated, Feb. 12, 1885.

I will be glad to see your article
in the Oct. Hygeia. Until recently I did not
know that you made an address at
the dedication of the painting. Could you
spare me 20 of the reprints? I will
be most interested, of course, and want
to provide some of my old friends with
copies. I will be glad to pay for them.

Yesterday I sent Kean my mmr.
as recently revised. I had two carbons
made this time and am circulating
them again among the old timers
to find all the errors possible. About
three months ago I asked if you
had written to Dr. Pinto after your
return from Cuba without any word
to me on the subject I finally wrote
AC
T
to him about two weeks ago and
had a very cordial letter from him.
So the second carbon went to him as
I feel sure he can give me some
real help on points which I am
hazy about. In due time I will
see that one of the copies comes to
you and you will see that I have really
worked on this one. The first was only
a typed copy of my first ideas and
should never have been typed in
that shape. I am sorry that you put so
much work on it, but after all it did
have info. that you wanted, I think.

In a few days I will return your
Bullard letter with comments.

Mrs Truby is in Phila. with one
of our daughters who is due right
now to become a mother. I am
all on edge each time the phone
on door bell rings, and have been
for a week. It is something to
become a grandpop at 70!

This is a messy and hasty letter
but its the best I can do to_ night.
